On Thu, Apr 17, 2008 at 11:13 PM, Kenneth Stanley
<kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> One thing to note about the particular experiment on checkers reported
>  in the AAAI paper is that its performance level against humans was by
>  intention not its focus.
>
>  Rather, our aim in this paper was simply to demonstrate that being
>  able to learn from geometry provides a critical advantage.

Fair enough, and I think the paper does what it aims to do very well.

>  Yet as Jason mentioned we have also run separately some coevolutionary
>  runs, and those the ones where it does become interesting what level
>  of human player can be defeated. Nevertheless, Jeff and Derek, I
>  agree with your criticisms of this kind of sensational claim (e.g.
>  "beats masters level player!") so we need to be careful to put any
>  such claim in context if we come to the point where we get results
>  like that.
>
>  And Derek, thanks for the Go link, very interesting!

No problem. Even though I'm not focused on AI for games, I still like
to try to keep up with what's going on in the field. If people are
making comparisons to Deep Blue and Kasparov, I think they are
analogous. I don't think Deep Blue was any sort of meaningful step
toward general-purpose AI, and I don't think algorithms like MoGo are
either. But who knows? I'm willing to be convinced otherwise. :)

--Derek
